node.text: Rachel Gurjar (@rachelgurjar) is showing us her take on a classic gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from her Indian heritage. With curry leaves, mango, and lime juice, this tangy and super refreshing cocktail feels like summer in a glass. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Curry Leaf and Mango G&T

node.text: Al Thompson (@drunkenmixologist) shares his version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. With the combination of bright, citrusy grapefruit and floral lavender, this G&T becomes the perfect rooftop cocktail. Simple. Refreshing. Delicious. #StirCreativity

node.text: Watch as @eatwithchrissy makes a tangy, slightly spicy margarita using @cointreau_us, Scotch bonnet peppers, grapefruit, lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita uses Scotch Bonnet peppers to give a satisfying kick.

node.title: Margarita Season: Scotch Bonnet and Grapefruit Margarita

node.text: Watch as @andybaraghani makes a sweet and refreshing margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled pineapple and mint, and lime, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita is quite possibly *the* drink of summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Crushed Pineapple and Mint Margarita

node.text: Melissa Miranda (@meltronica) shares her version of a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus, taking inspiration from the Philippines with a riff on the Gin Pom. With grapefruit, ginger, cardamom bitters, a squeeze of lime, and @bombaysapphireus, this drink will remind you of being on the beach. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Ginger Grapefruit G&T

node.text: Julie Reiner (@mixtressnyc) is showing us how to make her spin on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. Julie grew up in Hawai'i and uses that for her inspiration, with watermelon, lemon, and coconut water for a bright burst of summer. #StirCreativity

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Watermelon Coconut G&T

node.text:
**Sound On** In honor of Mother’s Day, best-selling author and poet Kwame Alexander (@kwamealexander) asked 12 accomplished writers to reflect on how their lives—and their kitchens—mirror their mothers. Everyone got the same prompt, “I am becoming my mother,” and this community poem is a result. Head to the link in our bio to read more about the authors.
Contributors: @vanggarrett, Lesléa Newman, @engle.margarita, @marjorythw, Richard Michelson, Janet Wong, @georgiaheard1, @amstephens_, Maritza Rivera, Reuben Jackson, Lorna Goodison, @erikalsanchez, Deanna Nikaido, and Kwame Alexander

node.title: Kwame Alexander Reads The Ceremony of Giving

node.text: Watch as @empschultz makes a salty blueberry and ginger Margarita using @cointreau_us, muddled blueberry, ginger simple syrup, and blanco tequila. This riff on The Original Margarita was inspired by a blueberry, ginger, and orange pie she made last summer.

node.title: Margarita Season: Salty Blueberry & Ginger Margarita

node.text: DeVonn Francis (@tuna__turner) is showing us how to make his unique take on a gin and tonic with @bombaysapphireus. DeVonn uses pineapple as a nod to his Caribbean roots, celery to compliment the herbaceous notes in the gin, and bay leaf to tie all the ingredients in his Pineapple Celery G&T.

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Pineapple Celery G&T

node.title: 99 Gin and Tonics: Black Pepper G+T

node.text: #Ad Esther Choi (@choibites), chef/owner of @mokbar_nyc, is showing us how to make a mandu stir-fry with lots of vegetables and of course, @bibigoUSA’s mandu.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 12, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: Quickly sautéed greens are a staple side dish for busy nights. But when you have 20 more minutes to spare, test kitchen director Chris Morocco (@moroccochris) encourages you to cook down piles of greens with well-browned onions, LOTS of garlic, and a handful of Parm to turn them into something really special. And don’t even think about skimping on the garlic! It won’t be overwhelming, we promise. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @emmafishman 🍴: @rebeccajurkevich 🥣: @sophiestrangio

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 11, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, food and indoor.

node.text: Carrots and chickpeas rise to stardom with the help of recipe developer Hetty McKinnon’s (@hettymckinnon) cashew cream recipe. Roasted to perfection and topped with crispy chickpeas, the sweet-savory carrots are taken to the next level when drizzled with a rich, nutty, herb-packed sauce. This recipe is part of our meal planning package, where one recipe (the incidentally vegan cashew cream) can become three quick weeknight meals. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @mpearljones 🥣: Anne Eastman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 11, 2021. May be an illustration.

node.text: 9/11 brought New York City restaurants to their knees. 20 years later, they face a different crisis. We talk to a chef and a restaurant owner who were at Ground Zero on that day, and reflect on what recovery—for the city and its restaurants—could look like now. Read more at the link in our bio. 🎨: @jackson.e.joyce

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 10, 2021. May be an image of chow mein.

node.text: The three-ingredient sauce used to dress these noodles showcases the grassy, spicy flavor of Thai basil. Associate food editor Jessie YuChen (@thelescook) quick-fries the basil-garlic purée with rice wine, bringing out the fragrance of the herb and mellowing the sharpest notes of raw garlic without completely muting them. The result? A savory, aromatic green sauce that clings perfectly to wide noodles. Top it all off with crunchy fried garlic or shallots, mung bean sprouts, garlic chives, and a jammy soft-boiled egg, and you’ve got a big flavor bowl meal that’s perfect for weeknights. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @rice.isnice 🥣: @aeswist

Recipe developer Hetty McKinnon (@hettymckinnon) thinks broccoli soup should be a foundational part of everyone’s weeknight cooking. It can be a dress-it-up or dress-it-down situation—packed with cheddar to bring that familiar oozy saltiness, or decked out fancy toppings, or simply served with croutons. This unintentionally vegan version by is simple yet packed with complexity, with a base of rich cashew cream that adds body, nuttiness, and an almost cloudlike consistency. This recipe is part of our meal planning package, where one recipe (the incidentally vegan cashew cream) can become three quick weeknight meals. Click the link in our bio to get this soup in your easy dinner rotation. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @mpearljones 🥣: Anne Eastman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 09, 2021. May be an illustration of 1 person.

node.text: ​​Billie Jean King (@billiejeanking) is familiar with the concept of a small dinner party. In fact, in her new autobiography, “All In,” she describes hitting with Rod Laver and Margaret Smith as the tennis court version of that classic party question: If you could have dinner with any three people, alive or dead, who would you choose? And yet, when editor in chief Dawn Davis (@bonappetitdawn) asked her nearly that exact question, she didn’t want to pick just three people. Or rather, she couldn’t. King’s dream dinner party is more like a raucous open house; Indian takeout and everyone’s invited. Read about it via the link in our bio. 🎨: @joanaavillez

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 09, 2021. May be an image of fruit.

node.text: There’s much debate about the best way to store tomatoes. Some maintain that storing them in the refrigerator turns them mealy and unpalatable; others say it doesn’t make any difference at all. But when you’ve gone through all the trouble of picking out the finest specimens at the farmers market, keeping them at their best is crucial. Turns out that there’s one guiding principle to follow: Where you should store your tomatoes depends on their state of ripeness. Senior editor Sarah Jampel (@sarahjampel) gives us the low-down on how to store tomatoes to ensure you enjoy them at their ripest and most flavorful. Click the link in our bio for the complete explanation. 📷: @yungbludlau

user.full_name: R A W L S T O N 🇻🇨

node.text: Sharp knives, hot oil, open flames - even the professionals among us are bound to pick up an injury with the number of hazards in the kitchen. Watch the full video on YouTube at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 08, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: Sure, we like the idea of meal prep, but having the same dinner on repeat can be, well, a bit of a drag. That’s where things like mother sauces, soup bases, and sauces come in. Our favorite kind of meal planning involves making one base recipe that you can use to make a number of speedy dinners throughout the week that all feel brand new—and that’s exactly what we’ll be giving you for the next three weeks. We’re starting off strong with a rich, incidentally vegan cashew cream from the brilliant Hetty McKinnon (@hettymckinnon) and three amazing dishes that are a snap to make once you’ve got a stash in the fridge. Tap that link in our bio to learn about a better kind of meal prep. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @mpearljones 🥣: Anne Eastman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 07, 2021. May be an image of strawberry and dessert.

node.text: Baked dishes rule recipe production assistant Mehreen Karim’s (@reeniekarim) world. Few things are as satisfying to make as a bubbling eggplant parm, a sheet of strawberry snacking cake, or any other dish that comes together in a single 9x13" pan. There’s only one problem: Though her heart wants to bake for a small town’s worth of folks, she lives in a household of two, and there is only so much baked ziti and custardy French toast that two can eat. Enter her new kitchenware MVP: the Sweejar baking dish. Click the link in our bio to read more about this small but sturdy (and super easy to clean) baking dish. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @rice.isnice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 07, 2021. May be an image of chow mein.

node.text: Rich, luxurious cashew cream is the star of this vegetarian weeknight noodle dish from recipe developer Hetty McKinnon (@hettymckinnon). Its delicately sweet with a hint of nuttiness, and has an incredibly silky texture that clings lovingly to every strand of noodle. And it pairs especially well with crispy pan-fried mushrooms, which provide big pops of umami flavor. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: @isa.zapata 🍴: @mpearljones 🥣: Anne Eastman

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by bonappetitmag on September 06, 2021. May be an image of food.

node.text: Chef-author-activist Bryant Terry’s (@bryantterry) luscious jackfruit tamales are not only a fascinating look at the crossover between Mexican and African American foodways, but proof that truly great tamales don’t require meat. Terry created this recipe in honor of the tamales he grew up eating, sold by an independent Black food vendor known as the “Tamale Man” who parked outside a Memphis skating rink. In a nod to the Southern African American tradition of tamale-making, he uses grits (a hot tamale staple) in the dough instead of masa. And to make them vegan, Terry fills the tamales with jackfruit, a tropical fruit that mimics the texture of meat. Click the link in our bio for the recipe. 📷: Oriana Koren 🍴: @mrsmochi 🥣: @jjoules
